Authors: Banaszynski, L.A., Wen, D., Dewell, S., Whitcomb, S.J., Lin, M., Diaz, N., Elsässer, S.J., Chapgier, A., Goldberg, A.D., Canaani, E., Rafii, S., Zheng, D., Allis, C.D.
Title: Hira-dependent histone H3.3 deposition facilitates prc2 recruitment at developmental loci in ES cells
Affiliations: Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Howard Hughes Medical Institute, Department of Genetic Medicine, Weill Cornell Medical College, New York, NY 10065, United States; Genomics Resource Center, Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Department of Genetics, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States; Molecular Medicine Unit, Institute of Child Health, London WC1N 1EH, United Kingdom; Department of Molecular Cell Biology, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot 76100, Israel; Departments of Neurology and Neuroscience, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States
Authors with affiliations: Banaszynski, L.A., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Wen, D., Howard Hughes Medical Institute, Department of Genetic Medicine, Weill Cornell Medical College, New York, NY 10065, United States; Dewell, S., Genomics Resource Center, Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Whitcomb, S.J., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Lin, M., Department of Genetics, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States; Diaz, N., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Elsässer, S.J., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Chapgier, A., Molecular Medicine Unit, Institute of Child Health, London WC1N 1EH, United Kingdom; Goldberg, A.D., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Canaani, E., Department of Molecular Cell Biology, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot 76100, Israel; Rafii, S., Howard Hughes Medical Institute, Department of Genetic Medicine, Weill Cornell Medical College, New York, NY 10065, United States; Zheng, D., Department of Genetics, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States, Departments of Neurology and Neuroscience, Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY 10461, United States; Allis, C.D., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States
Abstract: Summary Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) regulates gene expression during lineage specification through trimethylation of lysine 27 on histone H3 (H3K27me3). In Drosophila, polycomb binding sites are dynamic chromatin regions enriched with the histone variant H3.3. Here, we show that, in mouse embryonic stem cells (ESCs), H3.3 is required for proper establishment of H3K27me3 at the promoters of developmentally regulated genes. Upon H3.3 depletion, these promoters show reduced nucleosome turnover measured by deposition of de novo synthesized histones and reduced PRC2 occupancy. Further, we show H3.3-dependent interaction of PRC2 with the histone chaperone, Hira, and that Hira localization to chromatin requires H3.3. Our data demonstrate the importance of H3.3 in maintaining a chromatin landscape in ESCs that is important for proper gene regulation during differentiation. Moreover, our findings support the emerging notion that H3.3 has multiple functions in distinct genomic locations that are not always correlated with an "active" chromatin state. © 2013 Elsevier Inc.

Authors: Whitcomb, S.J., Fierzs, B., McGinty, R.K., Holt, M., Ito, T., Muir, T.W., Allis, C.D.
Title: Histone monoubiquitylation position determines specificity and direction of enzymatic cross-talk with histone methyltransferases Dot1L and PRC2
Affiliations: Lab. of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, Rockefeller University, 1230 York Ave., New York, NY 10065, United States; Laboratory of Synthetic Protein Chemistry, Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Department of Chemistry, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States; Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Nagasaki University School of Medicine, Nagasaki 852-8523, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Whitcomb, S.J., Lab. of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, Rockefeller University, 1230 York Ave., New York, NY 10065, United States; Fierzs, B., Department of Chemistry, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States; McGinty, R.K., Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA 16802, United States; Holt, M., Laboratory of Synthetic Protein Chemistry, Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Ito, T., Nagasaki University School of Medicine, Nagasaki 852-8523, Japan; Muir, T.W., Department of Chemistry, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States; Allis, C.D., Lab. of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, Rockefeller University, 1230 York Ave., New York, NY 10065, United States
Abstract: It is well established that chromatin is a destination for signal transduction, affecting many DNA-templated processes. Histone proteins in particular are extensively post-translationally modified. We are interested in how the complex repertoire of histone modifications is coordinately regulated to generate meaningful combinations of "marks" at physiologically relevant genomic locations. One important mechanism is "cross-talk" between pre-existing histone post-translational modifications and enzymes that subsequently add or remove modifications on chromatin. Here, we use chemically defined "designer" nucleosomes to investigate novel enzymatic cross-talk relationships between the most abundant histone ubiquitylation sites, H2AK119ub and H2BK120ub, and two important histone methyltransferases, Dot1L and PRC2. Although the presence of H2Bub in nucleosomes greatly stimulated Dot1L methylation of H3K79, we found that H2Aub did not influence Dot1L activity. In contrast, we show that H2Aub inhibited PRC2 methylation of H3K27, but H2Bub did not influence PRC2 activity. Taken together, these results highlight how the position of nucleosome monoubiquitylation affects the specificity and direction of cross-talk with enzymatic activities on chromatin. © 2012 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.

Authors: Milne, T.A., Kim, J., Wang, G.G., Stadler, S.C., Basrur, V., Whitcomb, S.J., Wang, Z., Ruthenburg, A.J., Elenitoba-Johnson, K.S.J., Roeder, R.G., Allis, C.D.
Title: Multiple Interactions Recruit MLL1 and MLL1 Fusion Proteins to the HOXA9 Locus in Leukemogenesis
Affiliations: Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Laboratory of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Structural Biology Program, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York, NY 10065, United States; Department of Pathology, Division of Translational Research, University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Milne, T.A., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Kim, J., Laboratory of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Wang, G.G., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Stadler, S.C., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Basrur, V., Department of Pathology, Division of Translational Research, University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Whitcomb, S.J., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Wang, Z., Structural Biology Program, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York, NY 10065, United States; Ruthenburg, A.J., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Elenitoba-Johnson, K.S.J., Department of Pathology, Division of Translational Research, University of Michigan Medical School, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States; Roeder, R.G., Laboratory of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States; Allis, C.D., Laboratory of Chromatin Biology and Epigenetics, The Rockefeller University, New York, NY 10065, United States
Abstract: MLL1 fusion proteins activate HoxA9 gene expression and cause aggressive leukemias that respond poorly to treatment, but how they recognize and stably bind to HoxA9 is not clearly understood. In a systematic analysis of MLL1 domain recruitment activity, we identified an essential MLL1 recruitment domain that includes the CXXC domain and PHD fingers and is controlled by direct interactions with the PAF elongation complex and H3K4Me2/3. MLL1 fusion proteins lack the PHD fingers and require prebinding of a wild-type MLL1 complex and CXXC domain recognition of DNA for stable HoxA9 association. Together, these results suggest that specific recruitment of MLL1 requires multiple interactions and is a precondition for stable recruitment of MLL1 fusion proteins to HoxA9 in leukemogenesis. Since wild-type MLL1 and oncogenic MLL1 fusion proteins have overlapping yet distinct recruitment mechanisms, this creates a window of opportunity that could be exploited for the development of targeted therapies. © 2010 Elsevier Inc.

Authors: Whitcomb, S.J., Basu, A., Allis, C.D., Bernstein, E.
Title: Polycomb Group proteins: an evolutionary perspective
Affiliations: Lab of Chromatin Biology, The Rockefeller University, 1230 York Ave, New York, NY 10065, United States
Authors with affiliations: Whitcomb, S.J., Lab of Chromatin Biology, The Rockefeller University, 1230 York Ave, New York, NY 10065, United States; Basu, A., Lab of Chromatin Biology, The Rockefeller University, 1230 York Ave, New York, NY 10065, United States; Allis, C.D., Lab of Chromatin Biology, The Rockefeller University, 1230 York Ave, New York, NY 10065, United States; Bernstein, E., Lab of Chromatin Biology, The Rockefeller University, 1230 York Ave, New York, NY 10065, United States
Abstract: The chromatin-associated Polycomb Group (PcG) proteins were first identified in genetic screens for homeotic transformations in Drosophila melanogaster. In addition to body patterning in metazoans, members of the PcG are now known to regulate epigenetic cellular memory, pluripotency and stem cell self-renewal. Here, we discuss the functional versatility of the PcG family and the evolutionary history of a subset of these proteins including Drosophila E(z), Pc, Psc, dRing and their homologs in plants and animals. We propose that PcG gene expansion and diversification contributed significantly to the complexity of heritable gene repression mechanisms in extant multicellular organisms. © 2007 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
